initial_story: My observation is there exists unequal share of State monies with its residents, before all the Urban residents get defensive please hear me out. Presently no one except Corporations pay State income taxes. No individual pays state taxes. I noticed state funded bicycle paths, road maintenance, defunct Docks, powerful politicians pet projects such as office buildings, state troopers etc, etc. all these fundings and more are not necessary within City limits, I was amazed at how much our state provides city functions in the bigger cities thus growing the state budget, I saw on tv last night how adg&g was showing the little ones how to ice fish, couldn't the parents do that? yes I pay property taxes. But I will guarantee you once our City folk get the full bill with out the State monies we will not be as wasteful, on the office building...rent what space you need and help the office rental marked. In my business I just retired from,I would ask my managers, "how do you stop spending money"?

The observation is that there is an unequal distribution of state monies among its residents. Before all the urban residents get defensive, please hear me out. Currently, no one except corporations pays state income taxes. No individual pays state taxes. I noticed that state-funded bicycle paths, road maintenance, defunct docks, and powerful politicians' pet projects, such as office buildings, state troopers, etc., are not necessary within city limits. I was amazed at how much our state provides city functions in the bigger cities, thus growing the state budget. I saw on TV last night how ADG&G was showing the little ones how to ice fish. Couldn't the parents do that? Yes, I pay property taxes. But I will guarantee you once our City folk get the full bill without the state monies, we will not be as wasteful. For example, in my business, I asked my managers, "how do you stop spending money?"

The observation is that there is an unequal distribution of state monies among its residents. Before all the urban residents get defensive, please hear me out. Currently, no one except corporations pays state income taxes. No individual pays state taxes. I noticed that state-funded bicycle paths, road maintenance, defunct docks, and powerful politicians' pet projects, such as office buildings, state troopers, etc., are not necessary within city limits. I was amazed at how much our state provides city functions in the bigger cities, thus growing the state budget. I saw on TV last night how ADG&G was showing the little ones how to ice fish. Couldn't the parents do that? Yes, I pay property taxes. But I will guarantee you once our City folk get the full bill without the state monies, we will not be as wasteful. For example, in my business, I asked my managers, "how do you stop spending money?"

As a citizen of the United States, I am deeply concerned about the current state of our society and the role that corporations play in it. It seems that many of our leaders, particularly those in positions of power and authority, are more interested in protecting their own interests and advancing their own agendas than in serving the public good. This is especially true when it comes to issues related to corporate welfare and the distribution of state monies.

For example, consider the recent debate over the state income tax. While many people believe that this tax is necessary to fund essential public services, such as education, healthcare, and infrastructure, others argue that it is unfair and burdensome, particularly for low-income and working-class individuals. In my view, this debate highlights the larger problem of corporate welfare and the unequal distribution of state monies among its residents.

I believe that it is time for us to rethink our priorities and focus on creating a more equitable and just society. This means putting the needs of ordinary citizens above the interests of powerful corporations and ensuring that everyone has equal access to opportunities and resources. It also means holding our leaders accountable for their actions and demanding greater transparency and accountability in government.

I am also concerned about the role that state-funded projects, such as bicycle paths, road maintenance, and defunct docks, play in our society. While these projects may have some benefits, I believe that they are often wasteful and unnecessary, particularly in light of the many challenges facing our communities, such as poverty, homelessness, and healthcare. I believe that we should prioritize investments in education, healthcare, and infrastructure, rather than spending money on projects that primarily benefit the wealthy and well-connected.

Overall, I believe that it is time for us to have a serious conversation about the state of our society and the role that corporations play in it. I believe that we have a responsibility to work together to create a more just and equitable society, one that puts the needs of ordinary citizens above the interests of powerful corporations and ensures that everyone has equal access to opportunities and resources.
